title: 106_hr4951
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Beneficiaries' Choice Stabilization Act of 2000" and includes a table of contents. The "Medicare Beneficiaries' Choice Stabilization Act of 2000" includes provisions such as establishing a payment floor for Medicare+Choice rates, changing budget neutrality adjustments, increasing national per capita growth percentage, allowing movement to a 50:50 blend, and permitting higher negotiated rates in certain payment areas. Sec. 10 delays the deadline for offering and withdrawing Medicare+Choice plans for 2001 from July to November 2000. Sec. 11 includes miscellaneous regulatory changes. Establishment of payment floor for Medicare+Choice payment rates after applying risk-adjustment methodology. The amendment to the Social Security Act establishes a demographically adjusted fee-for-service per capita expenditure for Medicare+Choice payment rates, calculated without certain adjustments. The amendment to the Social Security Act establishes a demographically adjusted fee-for-service per capita expenditure for Medicare+Choice payment rates, calculated without certain adjustments. Additionally, a special rule for risk adjustment is applied to the payment amount determined for a demographic class, following the methodology applied by the Secretary under section 1876(a)(4) without regard to subsection (a)(3) of this section. The Secretary is also required to continue computing and publishing county-specific per capita fee-for-service expenditure information using the most recent data available. The Secretary will compute and publish annual per capita costs for each Medicare+Choice payment area alongside the annual Medicare+Choice capitation rates. SEC. 3. ELIMINATION OF BUDGET NEUTRALITY ADJUSTMENT FOR 2001 AND 2002. Amends Section 1853(c) of the Social Security Act to remove budget neutrality adjustment for 2001 and 2002.

SEC. 4. INCREASE IN NATIONAL PER CAPITA MEDICARE+CHOICE GROWTH PERCENTAGE IN 2001 AND 2002. Amends Section 1853(c)(6)(B) of the Social Security Act to increase the national per capita Medicare+Choice growth percentage for 2001 and 2002.

SEC. 5. INCREASING MINIMUM PAYMENT AMOUNT. SEC. 5. INCREASING MINIMUM PAYMENT AMOUNT. Amends the Social Security Act to increase the minimum payment amount to $450 for 2001 for all states and the District of Columbia. Effective starting in 2001. SEC. 6. ALLOWING MOVEMENT TO 50:50 PERCENT BLEND IN 2002. SEC. 6. ALLOWING MOVEMENT TO 50:50 PERCENT BLEND IN 2002. Amends the Social Security Act to allow Medicare+Choice organizations to choose between subparagraph (F) and subparagraph (E) for 2001 and 2002. Amendment to the Social Security Act allows for a higher payment rate for Medicare+Choice in certain areas from 2001 to 2005. The amendments do not impact the first time bonus payment under the Social Security Act. SEC. 8. Permitting higher negotiated rates in certain Medicare+Choice payment areas below national average. Section 1853(c)(1) of the Social Security Act is amended to allow Medicare+Choice organizations to negotiate higher rates with the Secretary in areas where the capitation rate would be lower than the United States per capita cost. This change applies starting from 2004. The capitation rate increase is based on audited data and cannot exceed the projected United States per capita cost. The maximum rate of increase is tied to the inflation rate in private health. The capitation rate increase is determined by audited data and is capped at the projected US per capita cost, with a maximum increase linked to private health inflation rates. Adjustments are made for demographic characteristics and to exclude prescription drug costs. Adjustments for over or under projections follow specific provisions for subsequent years. The capitation rate increase is determined by audited data and is capped at the projected US per capita cost, with a maximum increase linked to private health inflation rates. Adjustments are made for demographic characteristics and to exclude prescription drug costs. Adjustments for over or under projections follow specific provisions for subsequent years, applying in the same manner as such provisions apply under this paragraph. SEC. 9 amends the Social Security Act to phase in risk adjustment based on data from all settings over a 10-year period starting in 2004. SEC. 10 delays the deadline for offering and withdrawing Medicare+Choice plans for 2001 from July to November 2000. The deadline for Medicare+Choice organizations to withdraw or submit information for offering plans in 2001 is delayed from July 1, 2000, to November 1, 2000. Organizations can rescind withdrawal notices before November 1, 2000. The deadline for Medicare+Choice organizations to withdraw or submit information for offering plans in 2001 is delayed to November 1, 2000. Organizations can rescind withdrawal notices before the deadline. Amendment to the Social Security Act prohibits the submission of encounter data for risk adjustment methodology until complete requirements are issued. The Secretary must establish data submission requirements for Medicare+Choice organizations to support risk adjustment methodology, with an evaluation by an independent actuary to determine if the data elements are minimal. Post-stabilization guidelines are outlined in Section 1852(d)(2) of the Act. Post-stabilization guidelines in Section 1852(d)(2) of the Act state that post-stabilization care must be related to the emergency condition and the provider needs approval from Medicare+Choice organization within 2 hours of stabilization. Enrollment Process: Online enrollment is allowed for filing election forms electronically. There is a moratorium on changes in Medicare+Choice enrollment. The Secretary of Health and Human Services is prohibited from making changes to Medicare+Choice enrollment rules between the enactment of this Act and January 1, 2002, unless required by a change in statute.
